text: All right. Let's get started. You heard what the judge said. One man is dead, and now we must decide if another man will live or die. Premeditated murder is the most serious charge in our courts. If we vote guilty, we send him to the electric chair. That's mandatory.
Did the bailiff lock us in here? What do they think we are, crooks?
They lock us up for a little while...
It's standard procedure to lock the door. They don't want anyone sneaking off. As I was saying, if there is a reasonable doubt in your minds, we must declare the defendant not guilty.
I think we all know that. None of us fell asleep in there.
Yes, well this is a serious business and I want to make sure we all have a clear idea about why we are here.
He also said that if there is no reasonable doubt, he must be found guilty. Am I right? And this kid is obviously guilty.
The judge said if we unanimously determine that there is no reasonable doubt, then he must be found guilty.
Our verdict must be unanimous, one way or another. Guilty or not guilty. That's the law.
I say let's call for a vote. Let's see where we stand.
Anybody doesn't want to vote? All right. This has to be a four-to-nothing vote either way. Are we ready? All those voting guilty, raise your hands.
Boy-oh-boy, there's always one.
Okay, not guilty?
One. Right. Okay, three to one, guilty. Now we know where we stand.
He knifed his own father. Four inches into the chest. They proved it a dozen different ways. Do you want me to list them for you? What do you want?
Nothing, I just want to talk. If we are condemning him to die, at least we can give him a few minutes of our time. What's your hurry?
No hurry, but this case is pretty obvious. Why, I was convinced the first day. What's there to talk about? He's guilty.
Suppose you're wrong? I'm not saying that I believe his story or not. Maybe I don't.
So why'd you vote not guilty?
It's not so easy for me to raise my hand and send a boy off to die without talking about it first.
Who says it's easy for me? The old man heard him yell that he was going to kill his father. In his own words he's telling us he did it.
How many times have each of us said, 'I could kill you for doing that.' Or 'If you do that once more, I'll kill you.' We say it every day. It doesn't mean we're going to kill someone.
The kid said he was going to kill him, and he did kill him. End of story.
So what's bothering you? Why don't you think he's guilty? I'd like to hear it.
Yes, I agree. Let's hear your reasons. We want to give this boy a fair trial. That's our mandate.

Maybe no reason. But let's look at this boy's situation. Kicked around all his life, his mother dead since he was nine, his father in and out of jail. This boy has grown up in the school of hard knocks. He's wild and angry. You know why he's like that? Because someone knocked him on the head once a day, every day. He's had a pretty terrible nineteen years. We just owe him a few words, that's all.

We don't owe him anything. The kid's a killer. I've listened to words all week. The prosecutor, the defense attorney, the witnesses, the judge. And don't tell me you're taking the kid's testimony seriously? He's a born liar, all his kind are.
Only an ignorant man can believe that. Just because this kid is a different color than you...
Don't take it personally. We're all adults here. Let's get to the facts.
Well, what if the boy's story is true? We'd be condemning him to die on false testimony.
But surely, you're not suggesting that all the witnesses were lying?
No, but maybe they think they saw something when they really didn't. It's possible. The woman claimed to see the murder from across the street just as the lights went out.
Yeah, she said that she couldn't sleep. She was in bed and happened to be looking across the way at their apartment when she saw him stab his father.
She's claiming that she could recognize this boy from 60 feet away as the lights went out. What if she thought she saw him, but it was really someone else?
She stood in the courtroom and said she saw it, plain as day. Why would she lie?
I'd like to ask you something. You don't believe the boy. How come you believe the woman? She's one of them, too, isn't she?
You're a pretty smart fellow, aren't you? Who made you so wise? What are you, the kid's guardian angel? He's got nothing. The woman wouldn't lie. She'd have no reason to.
I've got to agree. Why would she perjure herself? She has nothing to gain.
I'm saying that it's possible she saw someone else. The boy claimed he was at the movies.

The movies! What a load of crap. This kid couldn't even remember the names of the movies he was supposed to have seen. Don't you remember the cop's testimony? I'm telling you, the kid made it all up. No one could confirm his alibi. This kid stinks of the gutter.
I've lived in a slum all my life. I used to play in a backyard that was filled with garbage. Maybe it still smells on me!
Gentlemen. Now, let's be reasonable. The facts are that two witnesses saw him stab his father at exactly 12:10 a.m.
No, that's not right. Only the woman claimed to have seen it.
What do you mean, claimed? She saw it. He's confusing you.
The old man only heard the body fall, he didn't see the stabbing. Then he said he saw the kid running down the stairs and out of the house. So he called the police.
I'm asking you, could the old man really see the person running down the stairs? His vision isn't very good. It was dark. Is it possible it was someone else?
Is it possible you're wasting our time? You keep going around in circles.
Is there a reasonable doubt that it could have been someone else? That's the question.
The old man could have seen him. He wasn't far away.
That's true. But the woman was far away, wasn't she? About 60 feet. Why are you rubbing your nose like that? I want to know why you are rubbing your nose.
Well, if it's any of your business, I was rubbing it because it bothers me a little. It is because of my eyeglasses. Now could we get on to something else?

Your eyeglasses make those deep impressions on the sides of your nose. I never noticed that before. They must be annoying. The woman who testified that she saw the killing had the same marks on the sides of her nose.
You're right. She kept rubbing them in the courtroom.
This woman was about forty-five years old, but she tried to look thirty-five. Did you notice that? All that make-up, her hair dyed, the brand new clothes. And no eyeglasses.
What do you mean, no eyeglasses? You don't know that she wore glasses. Just because she was rubbing her nose.
Listen, I saw them too. I was the closest one to her. She had these marks.
Could those marks be made by anything other than eyeglasses? I don't think so. And no one wears glasses to bed.

So it's logical to assume that if she was trying to fall asleep, and looked casually out the window, she wouldn't see much without her glasses on, especially from 60 feet away. She wouldn't have seen anything.
You don't know what kind of glasses she wore! You're guessing. They could have been sunglasses.
And here's another guess. Maybe she honestly thought she saw the boy kill his father. I say that she only saw a blur.
You haven't convinced anyone. I call for another vote.
What's your hurry? Are you his executioner? Maybe you'd like to pull the switch...
For this kid? You bet I would.
I feel sorry for you...What it must feel like to want to pull the switch! Ever since we walked into this room, you've been behaving like a self-appointed public avenger.
Listen, you shut up! I'm telling you now! Shut up!
You want to see this boy die because you personally want it, not because of the facts.
Shut up!
You're a sadist!
Shut up or I'll kill you!
You don't really mean you'll kill me, do you?
Another vote has been called for. Let's vote. Guilty?
Not-guilty?
